API: Application Programming Interface — a way for programs to communicate with each other through defined requests and responses.
REST: Representational State Transfer — an architectural style for web APIs using standard HTTP methods (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE).
SSR: Server-Side Rendering — generating HTML on the server for each request, improving SEO and initial load time.
SSG: Static Site Generation — pre-building all pages at build time so they can be served as plain files without a server.
CDN: Content Delivery Network — a distributed network of servers that caches and delivers content from locations closer to users.
CI/CD: Continuous Integration / Continuous Deployment — automating code testing and deployment so changes ship faster and safer.
ORM: Object-Relational Mapping — a library that lets you work with database records as code objects instead of writing raw SQL.
JWT: JSON Web Token — a compact, self-contained token format for securely transmitting authentication information between parties.
OAuth: Open Authorization — a protocol that lets apps access user data from another service without sharing passwords.
CORS: Cross-Origin Resource Sharing — a browser security mechanism that controls which domains can make requests to your server.
SEO: Search Engine Optimization — techniques to improve a page's ranking and visibility in search engine results.
TTL: Time To Live — how long cached content is considered fresh before it must be re-fetched or revalidated.
LCP: Largest Contentful Paint — a Core Web Vital that measures when the largest visible element finishes rendering.
WASM: WebAssembly — a binary instruction format that lets code written in languages like C++ or Rust run at near-native speed in browsers.
RSS: Really Simple Syndication — a standardized feed format that lets readers subscribe to content updates from websites.
DDoS: Distributed Denial of Service — an attack that floods a server with traffic from many sources to make it unavailable.
SVG: Scalable Vector Graphics — an XML-based image format that scales to any size without losing quality.
Astro: A web framework for building fast, content-driven static sites that ships minimal client-side JavaScript by default.
Next.js: A React framework for building full-stack web apps with built-in support for SSR, SSG, and API routes.
Preact: A fast, 3KB alternative to React with the same modern API — ideal when bundle size matters.
Tailwind CSS: A utility-first CSS framework where you style elements by composing small, single-purpose classes directly in HTML.
Docker: A platform for packaging applications into containers — lightweight, isolated environments that run consistently anywhere.
Playwright: A browser automation framework for end-to-end testing across Chromium, Firefox, and WebKit.
Drizzle: A lightweight TypeScript ORM that provides type-safe database queries with a SQL-like syntax.
Turso: A distributed SQLite database service built on libSQL, designed for edge deployment and low latency.
Vite: A fast build tool for modern web development with instant hot module replacement during development.
Webpack: A module bundler that packages JavaScript, CSS, images, and other assets into optimized bundles for the browser.
GraphQL: A query language for APIs that lets clients request exactly the data they need in a single request.
Hydration: The process where a server-rendered page becomes interactive by attaching JavaScript event handlers to the existing HTML.
Headless CMS: A content management system that provides content through an API, without a built-in frontend — you bring your own UI.
Edge Computing: Running server-side code on machines geographically close to users, reducing latency compared to a single central server.
Virtual DOM: An in-memory representation of the UI that frameworks like React use to calculate minimal updates before touching the real DOM.
Middleware: Code that runs between receiving a request and sending a response — commonly used for authentication, logging, or redirects.
WebSocket: A protocol for persistent, two-way communication between browser and server — unlike HTTP, the connection stays open.
Code Splitting: Breaking a large JavaScript bundle into smaller chunks that load on demand, so users only download what they need.
